bibl.title: Report to [Carlos E.] Finlay and General Grant on the Quinta San Jose, Quemados de Marianao, Cuba, by Frederick L. Rath, Jr., May 7, 1952

div1.p: Rath describes the Rojas family estate and the adjoining Camp Lazear in terms of their historic significance. He discusses preservation difficulties in Cuba, and outlines Rojas' suggestion that Building No. 1 be taken down and rebuilt on her San Jose property. Rojas would like both properties to be taken over by the American National Trust, and for the Trust to help in setting up a Cuban-American foundation to preserve the property.

div1.head: Report to [Carlos E.] Finlay and General Grant on the Quinta San Jose, Quemados de Marianao, Cuba, by Frederick L. Rath, Jr., May 7, 1952
div1.opener:
May 7, 1952
Mr. Finley and General Grant
Frederick L. Rath, Jr.
Quinta San José, Quemados de Marianao, Cuba
div1.p:
As you know, at the request and expense of Dr. Phillip S. Hench,
I went to Cuba at the end of my recent trip to Florida. There I stayed at
the Quinta San José, the estate of Senora Maria Teresa Rojas in the Havana
suburb.

This family estate has interesting American connections because
it was Senora Rojas' father who gave the land at the edge of his farm to
Walter Reed and a group of Cuban and American medical authorities early in
this century to conduct the final and conclusive experiments to determine
the cause of yellow fever. That site, named Camp Lazear, is no longer part
of the Rojas' old estate. In the slum now there, a single ramshackle struc-
ture, the so-called Building No. 1, where it was determined that yellow fever
cannot be transmitted by association with infected objects, still stands.
Occupied by one or more Cuban families, the frame building has been declared
a national monument. Two recent Cuban governments have appropriated money
for memorializing the site and preserving Building No. 1; nothing has been
done.

The Quinta San José is what remains of the old original farm. To-
day there are several walled acres in the busy suburb, as well as a fine home,
which, I am told, is typical of Cuba. The home is filled with a collection
of objects and art; it is a catholic collection, including European and Amer-
ican materials, which is said to be characteristic of Cuba. Not so charac-
teristic, perhaps, is the collection of early tiles, moldings, cornices,

and so forth, saved by Senora Rojas from buildings about to be destroyed in
Cuba.

Senora Rojas and her companion, Senorita Lydia Cabresa, are unusual
women. Both are students of history and authors; they are women of broad back-
ground and culture; finally, they are deeply concerned with the undoubted pass-
ing of the Cuban heritage of significant sites and buildings. Their efforts
to arouse support, to preserve some buildings have in the main failed. Dis-
trusting the particular vagaries of Cuban government, they are seeking not
only to help Dr. Hench assure the preservation of Camp Lazear site and Building
No. 1 but also to assure the permanent preservation of the Quinta San José.
Senora Rojas has no heirs for her property.

I visited the Camp Lazear site and am inclined to think that the
situation there is almost hopeless. Building No. 1 is backed by an operating
quarry; the present approach to it is confused and through a slum area. Only
$25,000 was available for the proposed memorial under the last (Prio) adminis-
tration. Dr. Henriquez Saladrigas, the present Minister of Health under Inte-
rim President Batista, dined with us at the Quinta San José one night and pro-
mised to investigate the present situation. In any event, perhaps as much as
$250,000 would be needed to treat the site effectively and it is doubtful that
the present government would consider so large an investment. Dr. Saladrigas'
report will clarify this point later.

Our concern with the situation focuses on a suggestion and offer made
by Senora Rojas. She wishes to arrange, if possible, for the taking down of
Building No. 1 and re-erection on a portion of the present Quinta San José.
Whether she will be able to do so, I don't know; ultimately, I suspect, that
will depend on her influence with the present government and particularly

President Batista. Furthermore, she wishes to provide for the preservation
of the Quinta San José, including Building No. 1, if it is moved, and any
museum adjunct she might erect, in one of two ways: First, she is willing,
if it is possible, to leave it by bequest, together with an endowment, to
our National Trust. Alternatively, she would like to have our moral support
in the setting up of a Cuban-American foundation that would receive the be-
quest and administer the property after her death.

I explained the difficulties in the former course to Senora Rojas,
told her that I had no authority to encourage such a hope, elaborated on the
legal and possibly diplomatic difficulties. She requested, however, that the
matter be brought to the attention of the Trustees of the National Trust, to
see whether they believed it would be possible to explore the problem further
with her. If the first course then fails - that is, acquisition by the Natio-
nal Trust, - then she would like to have our assistance in setting up the
Cuban-American foundation. While assuring her of our interest, I emphasized
the number and nature of the problems now confronting our relatively young
National Trust. She understood the position I took and could only express
the hope that the Trustees might help her to solve this problem. There is only
a slight hope that the Quinta San José can be permanently saved in any other
way; in fact, there is a lurking fear that the Quinta San José might even be
expropriated some day. There is no present Cuban agency, official or non-
governmental, to deal with the problem.

The general problem can be presented to the Trustees on Saturday morn-
ing, May 10th, if you are willing to have it placed on the agenda. At that time
I shall be happy to answer any questions or to discuss aspects of the problem
not here discussed. I believe that the Trustees should decide whether or not
this problem lies within the province of our National Trust. Such a decision
will enable us to determine our next move.
